Had I the wit of Newstead's noble bard</br>I'd sacrifice it all, again to be</br>The child I was, when on that smooth green sward</br>I drove my hoop along with mickle glee,</br>Or climb'd, with eager haste, yon cherry-tree.</br>Happy are they who need not e'er regret</br>The long-past days of careless infancy;</br>Whom friends have ne'er betray'd, nor knaves beset,</br>Who never have been caught in woman's subtle net.

Of this enough, — the storm has ceased to rage;</br>I live — but how, it matters not, — I live—</br>All, all is vanity — thus spoke the sage;</br>Yet there remains one pleasure — 'tis to give;</br>With some, 'tis pouring water through a sieve:</br>An endless folly, an excessive waste,</br>To feed their drones, these lordlings rob the hive;</br>They waste their wealth on fools or dames unchaste;</br>On gems, or jewels rare, these children have a taste.

DIVES had feasts at home, and many came</br>To see the strange inventions of the night;</br>Minstrels were in his halls, resembling flame,</br>The colour of their robes was very bright,</br>Ladies were clad in silk, all lily white,</br>While Burgundy, from golden goblets pour'd,</br>Freshen'd the heart of man with new delight,</br>And boon companions gather'd round his board;</br>Pledging the frequent health of their all-liberal lord.

But what is DIVES now? — a misanthrope—</br>A snarling cynic, basking in the sun;</br>O'ercharged with lust, he gave his passion scope;</br>A self-tormentor, now his course is run,</br>Mingling with fellow-men, yet loving none.</br>Divine Charissa calls on him in vain—</br>Though fools have robb'd thee, do not therefore shun</br>The sad retreat of penury and pain:</br>Sullen he stalks apart, and eyes her with disdain.

What wert thou born for, denizen of earth,</br>To laugh and grieve as suits thy wayward will;</br>Scoffer — the soul will have a second birth;—</br>Awake the song — the sparkling goblet fill;</br>Drown, in thy wine, all thoughts of future ill.</br>There is another world! — Then be it so—</br>Of this already have I had my fill!—</br>"This will not save thee — this fantastic woe:</br>Thou knowest not, wretched man, where thou art doom'd to go!"</br>
